participants.participant: Nishna Biyani, Analyst, Prabhudas Lilladher Pvt. Ltd.
D. K. Sarraf, Executive Director and Director of Finance
D. K. Sarraf, Executive Director & Director of Finance

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon and welcome to the ONGC Q1 FY '11 results conference call, hosted by Prabhudas Lilladher Private Limited. As a reminder, all participants' line will be in the listen-only mode. There will be an opportunity for you to ask questions at the end of today's presentation. Please note that this conference is being recorded.
Joining us on the call today from Prabhudas Lilladher is Ms. Amisha Vora and Mr. Dilip Bhat, Joint Managing Directors. I would now like to hand the conference over to Mr. Nishna Biyani.
Thank you. And over to you, sir.

Thank you. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. I'm Nishna here and we at Prabhudas Lilladher are very pleased to hold this conference call for the first quarter FY '11 results of ONGC. Today we have the senior management from ONGC, led by Mr. D. K. Sarraf, Director, Finance; Mr. B.L. Ghasolia, Advisor, Finance; Mr. Vijay Ranjan and Mr. L. Nelson, Chief Manager, FNDIRC.
The call will begin with some observations by Mr. Sarraf and the management team followed by a Q&A session. Over to you sir.

Thank you. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. I welcome you all in this ONGC earnings call for Q1 FY '11. I'm joined by Mr. Ghasolia, Advisor, Finance; Mr. Vijay Ranjan, General Manager of Training; Mr. Nelson, he is the Chief Manager and and we will be shortly be having somebody from ONGC Ltd with us.

The financial results for the first quarter of 2011 have been taken on this call by the Board of Directors of ONGC yesterday, that is on 29 of July 2010. These results have been posted on ONGC's website, as well as given to the print media for publication and I hope that all of you would have seen it. However for the benefit of everybody, let me give the proxies of these results.

Gross sales revenue stood at 13,710 crore as against 14,972 crore in Q1 FY '10. The net profit after-tax is 3,651 crore against 4,448 crore, that is a decrease of about 24.5%. The decrease in profit after-tax is mainly due to increased share of under recoveries of all marketing companies amounting to 5,515 crore rupees, which we have been asked to via during the quarter, as against 429 crore during the corresponding quarter last year. This has adversely impacted our profit after-tax by 3,119 crore rupees after accounting for the and asset benefits.

Gross billing for 2009 was $80.80 per barrel as against 60.58 in the same period last year. However, after giving discount by subsidy, the valuation for crude oil in this quarter was 48.04 per barrel as against 58.25 in the same period last year. That means there has been a decline in the net price of crude oil by more than $10 per barrel.

In addition, descending of Indian rupees during the first quarter of this fiscal has also impacted our gross revenue adversely. The exchange rate of rupee versus dollar was 45.67 vis-à-vis 48.67 in the first quarter of 2010. That means for each barrel of billing we earn three rupees less. As a result, after for crude oil in rupee terms was 2,194 rupees, 2,194 rupees per barrel in the current quarter as against 2,835 rupees per barrel in the quarterly quarter last year. This has an adverse impact of 862 crores on the sales revenues. So that means 862 crores was the impact of the exchange addition.

Then, as you are aware, the government of India has revised the price of APM gas with the effect from 1 of June 2010, as we develop $4.2 per MMBtu which includes . Because it favorably impacted our gas revenue by 539 crore rupees in the first quarter, though the impact during this quarter was only for one month.

Revenue from value-added product has also gone up by rupees 282 crore in this quarter. Income from interest and dividend has come down by rupees 380 crore mainly on account of less yield from investment. The averages during the corresponding quarter of the last year was 11.48%, which has come down to as low as 6.14% during this quarter in the review.

As all of you are aware, during the year 2009/2010, ONGC Board has decided not to charge any interest from its 100% subsidiary that only can be estimated from 1 April 2009. This has a negative impact of 290 crores during this quarter of this year. Also the decision was effective from 1 October 2009, but the adjustment was made in Q3 of last year; that means for the first quarter and second quarter we had made the provision of interest receivable from ONGC Videsh with a reverse during the third quarter.

The operating expenses during the first quarter of this year has increased by rupees 408 crores, mainly on account of increasing manpower, water induction, machine and maintenance and the transmission cost. At the same time, there's a marginal increase in workover expenditure and initiative expenditure and provision control expenditure. Overall I would say that the operating expenditure, bulk of the exchange variations are almost equal to the last year's level.

In Videsh, there has been no increase in the overall DD&A cost, in which through that 3,113 crore as against 3,179 crore during the first quarter of last year. However some increase in depletion and depreciation cost is mainly due to addition in the properties, especially Rajasthan and other physical infrastructure. At the same time, survey and rival costs have significantly come down from 1,911 crores last year to 1,470 crores in the first quarter of this year.

In terms of physical performance, whereas the gas production has been more or less static at 5.76 bcm billion cubic meter during this quarter versus 5.75 bcm in the same quarter last year. However there was a marginal reduction in oil production at 6.05 mmt, which is million metric ton in the first quarter of this year and of course to 6.12 mmt during the first quarter of last year. That means there is a decline of about 1% in the net production.

The production of value added products, namely LPG, Nasa, C2-C3, HQ, which was 864 tmt, which is thousand metric ton in first quarter last year was 801 tmt in the current quarter. For the domestic joint ventures, the question has been an increase of approximately 2% from 0.43 eventually last year to 0.55 mmt in Q1 of this year. The gas production has more or less been stable or stagnant for the joint venture at 0.65 bcm in this quarter versus 0.64 bcm in the same quarter of last year.

Some of the minute details about the adjusted results are already available on our website and hence I would request you to finish by leaving here and would be happy to take questions from all of you ladies and gentlemen. My colleagues Mr. Ghasolia, Mr. Vijay Ranjan, Mr. Nelson and now we have also been joined by Mr. Rakesh Sharma from and we would try to clarify whatever points you may have. Thank you and over to you.
Thank you very much sir. [Operator Instruction] The first question is from the line of Niraj Mansingka from Edelweiss Securities. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, sir. Sir this is regarding the sales data. The sales to production ratio for the company has come down dramatically. Could you throw some color on that, how the sales to ratio has come up?
I think Mr. Vijay Ranjan has already brought out some data on this question and I will request him to throw some light.

Good afternoon. See the ratio of sales to production has more or less been on what has been expected in this quarter, and the only thing this time, it so happened that some of the refineries had some technical problems; like Numaligarh refinery in Assam and Koyali refinery in Gujrat and HPCL refinery in Bombay. All three refineries had some technical problem and therefore the take offs were less than normal. And because of this there was a stock buildup of roughly around 138 million metric towards the quarter and that is the actual increase besides the normal gap between sales and production.
Okay. Yeah, that's all. Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Nipun Sharma from Mirea Asset Securities. Please go ahead.
Hi, good afternoon sir. Thanks for the appendix. Just wanted you to kindly remind us about your exploration development and deficit charges for the full year and how many were seen in Q1'11?
Yes, good afternoon Nipun.
Hi Mr. Ranjan.

Welcome. See this current fiscal FY '11, we are planning to drill 154 exploratory wells and 216 development wells and we have a production target of 25 million metric ton of oil from the domestic operations and 2 million metric tons from our share in the domestic JV, and 23 BCM of gas from our domestic operations and 2.2 bcm of gas from the joint venture.
And could you please give me the split between how many exploratory wells and development wells have been drilled already in the first quarter?
In the first quarter we have already drilled 28 exploratory wells and 54 development wells.
And the CapEx outlay for the full year and how much has been spent for the first quarter?
We have the figure for the full year, but the actual spend for the quarter is actually, we require some more time to compile that data.
Okay. No problem. The full year target?
Full year is 26,523 crores.
All right. Thank you.
Yeah.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Probal from IDFC. Please go ahead.

Yeah. Hi. Thank you for the opportunity. I just had a couple of questions. One was on OVL. I know its not part of the result, but if you can give some color on how production has progressed in OVL and what are your sort of outlook for production for the rest of the year.

And the second question was, what are the kind of estimates you are getting at the moment of subsidy for the rest of the year, of the total subsidy burden. I mean ONGC's share will perhaps be again a majority of that 33%, but what are the estimates for the total subsidy burden for the year?
Okay, I will answer the first part, that's the real production.
Right.
The Q1 production in this financial year has been about 2.3 million tons of oil and gas both put together.
Okay.
Which has about 1.7 million tons of oil and remaining is gas.
Okay.
And throughout the financial year, we expect more or less similar kind of a production profile that we have had in first quarter.
So that would be around sir, it's around 6.8 million tons of oil and about 2.5 BCM of gas, am I correct?

Yeah, something very close to that. I mean what we are targeting is about 8.6 million tons of both and oil and gas put together, factoring it. Various things that might happen during the next nine months, where we would have some wells which would have a lower productivity or we would be putting on some other wells into the production stream.
Okay. Okay. And the subsidy...

Yeah. On the subsidy, I would take this question. During this quarter already there is doubt which ODC has given or ODC has asked to give. It's 5515.54 crore against the total recovery which was born by the upstream, it's roughly 6690.50 crore.
Right.

Now a couple of things have happened in the recent past towards almost the end of the quarter. Firstly the government has increased the price of petroleum products as the government has been dealing with the prices of petrol. So this will have some positive impact on the total un-naturally position.

And during the current quarter, first quarter, it was not possible to account for any contribution from the government, because of the true position. So evidently it is expected to come during Q2 or Q3, and at that time we expect that the subsidiary contribution by upstream will be lower than what it has been in the first quarter.

Overall we will say that the subsidy who's at the whole of the year is expected to bet better than the first quarter, but however it would be difficult to predict. It will depend on various factors, including the global prices, the equity of the government to trade, especially on SSC sites and so on, and also very importantly the contribution in terms of idle points or projects which comes from the CFRS.

Sorry, just a small follow-up question sir, but the share, I mean irrespective of the government cash. I mean in terms of the timing and the mechanism of the government contribution, upstream would be still probably 33% of whatever burden it is for the rest of the year, is that correct?

It's difficult to say and to predict whether upstream consumption would be 33% or a different number. In the past, for several years it's been one-third of total facility contribution being made by Justin. But it's difficult say that whether the part will be repeated or not. It would depend on various factors.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Raj Gandhi from Principal Mutual Fund. Please go ahead.
Hello.
Yes, Mr. Gandhi. Good afternoon to you.
Good afternoon, sir. Sir I just would like to know how do you account for the royalty that you pay in the Cairn field, because 100% right is according to you?

As per the production sharing agreement, 100% of the royalty is to be paid by ONGC. And therefore, we have accounted for 100% of the royalty as expenditure. Also only 30% of the crude oil is received into ONGC's books...
Okay, so that can be fully reflected in your accounts?

Yes, it is already reflected in the accounts. That mean it is on the conservative side, whereas as you perhaps would be aware, been representing to the Government of India for which we paid on behalf of the operator Cairn. And we expect that some of the revision should come in the near future.
So just net of this royalty, what was the profit or loss from that Cairn JV?

I don't have the separate number of how much profit or gain we have made from the Cairn JV, but the fact remains that it would not be a profitable venture if we continue to bear 100% of the royalty against 30% of the revenue, but we are doing all of our best and we expect some resolution of the problem.

Right. And so just sir, your KG field FDP is approved. Will you write back the provision made earlier? Because I guess the UD value you already written it off, but once the FDP is approved, will you have to write it back?
I could not understand your question there.

Sir, this UD well which you have drilled, even though it was successful because you were not about to drill in that block for the foreseeable future, you had written-off that expenditure of I think about 900 crores. So will there be a...
Yeah, that's a very good question. We have made a provision we have not written-off.
Okay.
Had we written it off, there was no question of writing back.
Right.
Since it's a provision, we will need to take a call, depending on various factors, about whether that particular expenditure, that provision can be written back or not.
But have you already filed for the FDP or we are about to file for the FDP for KG?
FDP, we have not yet filed.
Okay. Hello.
Just a moment.
Yeah.

There are two parts of this block, the northern part and the southern parts. So, as the northern part is concerned we have filed the document on 16 of July this month. This is called the Declaration of Commerciality. For this northern discovery we have filed it. For the southern discovery, some more work is yet to be done and once the digits approves this Declaration of Commerciality. This is meant to develop this northern part which we call in the northern discovery area, along with certain nominative discoveries. In the nominated blocks we already framed it in and it will perhaps move forward.
Okay. So, what is the amount of CapEx and production end result of the declaration that you made?
It is too early to say that what is going to be the CapEx, but as far as the document which we have filed with DBS, the CapEx is expected to be approximately US $5 billion.
Okay. And the production under this?

I mean again, the production as we go forward would need to be filed soon, both from the NDA which is NEFT block as well as the nominated block, but the production which we have at this every point in time is 86.97, about 87 Bcm of gas production and 4.5 million of crude production over the thin line and the deep production is expected to be in 2016 which is about 13 Bcm of gas, plus, about 8 Mnc of oil.
Okay. And sir, just what is the gas price and the working that has been done for the declaration?
These are matters of commercial detail and at this stage we would not like to divulge it.
Okay, and for the southern area, how soon are you supposed to file the declaration?

Mr. Vijay Ranjan tells me that we are yet to do certain jobs for the southern area and that some more time is available even as the norms to file the document of DOC and would take about six to 12 months for that.
Okay, sir. Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Vidyadhar Ginde from DSP Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Yeah, good afternoon. In fact, a lot of my questions have been answered. But just to clarify further, on the Rajasthan thing, as and when the government accepts your suggestion, is it going to be the composition, is it going to be retrospective? And when do you expect the resolution? Do you expect it in the current year?

Vidyadhar, we have been trying for resolution since 1998, it's been 12 years. So for me to say today that how much it would take is very difficult, but what I can say is that the decision with the government in various ministries is at a very advanced stage, and now there has been a realization in the government also that what ONGC has been saying all these years, more than a decade, is quite reasonable.

ONGC has agreed to develop this block in the vested interest based on certain conditions which were made by the government, and hence it needs to be reimbursed to ONGC. But it's difficult at this point in time to give timeline, that how much time it would take. And obviously we have transferred the investment from the constructive effects.

Okay, and the second question was again relating to KG, though a lot it has been answered. Two clarifications; one is that the numbers which you mentioned, I presume are for recoverable reserves. Are they only relating to the northern portion, and what was the oil recoverable number? Was it 4.5 million tons or what was it?

Yeah. I want to repeat that. First of all, the numbers which I said, they are of recoverable reserves. That is the cumulative production profile of the discoveries and the discoveries here mean the northern development area of the KG block, plus certain other discoveries from the nomination block. So we would be combining these two areas, which would be one of the first in India to have a development of the nomination block, as well as the NESP blocks. The cumulative production in the field is 4.5 million tons, and the peak production again happens in 2016, which is 0.841 million tons.

Okay. And the last question in this context is that, are you likely to still have 65% stake in this field because you have palmed out stakes to players, which I think at least one or both of them are gone out, so what's the status on that? I think eventually you're likely to have 65% stake or higher.

These details are getting worked out today. Practically we own 90% of the participating interest in this field and going forward, how much we own and how much we form out if any, those details are getting worked out. We are in discussions with the different companies, but nothing has been finalized as yet.
Yes, thanks. Just one more thing, that when is the production expected to start oil and gas from the northern development area?
As per the documents which we have filed with the DTH, it is 2016 calendar.
So it starts in FY '16, is it?
Ideally, between 2016 calendar. Now one minute; any of my other colleagues may have a better information on this. 2016 calendar.
But I thought that was the peak year, that's the start year is it?
That's start year as well.
Okay.

There is two wells we plan to drill. So in the first year itself we achieved the peak production and the only thing I'm not very sure is whether this 2016 refers to the calendar year or the financial year. Perhaps it's calendar year.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Rakesh Sethia from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Yes, thank you very much sir for the opportunity. My question is regarding the excess inventory buildup which has happened in the western area. When do you think this will translate into – is this going to happen quicker or it's going to let's say in one quarter or it will take some more time and spread over a few quarters?

Well, these are a very temporary phenomenon, which always happen sometime in the oil industry. Some of the refineries, they do go for planned shutdowns. Even unplanned shutdowns also do take place in the refineries. So we have some storage capacity. The refineries also have some storage capacity.

So here in this quarter, there was some problem with reference to the heavy oil in Gujarat, which we have been acquiring finally. As well as in the northeast there was problem in the minor refineries, plus the HPCL refineries are also uplifting the crude below their normal uptake. It will be built up on gas and we expect that trading, it would come to be normal very soon. It's not a cause of concern to us.
Okay, sir. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Amit Shah from BNP Paribas. Please go ahead. Mr. Shah, your line has been unmated, you may go ahead please.
Hello.
Yes. Please go ahead.
Hi, good afternoon.
Good afternoon.

Just a couple of questions, one on the KG basin field, you know where TATA oil and Petrobras backed out. Now what is the status on that? And how soon do we see partnership happening, as well as what's the outline of basically the production if any by them and when do you expect it?
And second question is on, how do you expect the gas growth? Would it be flat year-on-year for FY'11 and just for the next a couple years if you can explain? Thanks a lot.

Yes. So we can see the exit of certain partners in the KG block. They express their desire to quit the block, the candidate in the early season. So as NP is concern, as we just said we are working on the various proposals, but no decision has been taken, but let me assure you that we ourselves are capable technically and financially to complete the development and we are taking necessary actions towards that.

The last part of the question, that I think it was on gas production. As I just said, there are two, three areas on which the gas or pipe would come. Firstly, in 2011 and 2012 beginning, the production from Tripura would increase substantially once the power plant of ONGC Tripura Power Company is commissioned.

I would increase from 1.5 million cubic meters per day to almost 6 million cubic meter per day. Then we have increased in C-Series a gas production, which at present is 1.1 million cubic meter per day and perhaps it would increase to 3 to 4 million cubic meter per day. This too would happen in the short run.

The two wells which are longer in term, one is NDA and the nomination block which I just said happening in 2016, as well as we would have a substantial increase in gas production from Daman area, as well as certain developments we have there. Plus on the east side we have DL15 and D1, which is likely to come in the production from 2011-12, which is likely to be 2 million cubic meters per day.
Okay. Great. Thank you. And one more question on, what was the gain share that ONGC recorded this quarter?
The gain share in?
No, basically the changed production, what has ONGC shared from the Ken field this quarter.
You are talking of ramping.
Yes.
It has 70% and we have 30%. So we have accounted for 30% of the revenue, but from the rising standpoint, we have accounted for 100% of the rising to our account.
Okay and just one more, on the KG field, what was the reserve number for that approved region please?
KG field?
Yeah, the KG bases locked at ONGC.

No. We have not booked any reserve to my understanding. We have only said that we are submitting a document called Declaration of Commerciality to begin, but we are yet to account for any reserve from this block.
And that was something around 2.5 Tcf, right, if I am not correct.
Yes. You are aware, but I am not aware of any results.
Okay. No problem. Thank you very much sir.
Thank you. There is follow-up question from the line of Probal from IDFC. Please go ahead.

Hi. Sorry for not completing my questions. Just one small things, the recent approval that has happened over the drilling moratorium, I just wanted to understand, is there any immediate near-term impact, any drilling activity or development activity that will accelerate because of this.

ONGC as the national company, we were very – I think that this drilling moratorium would come and we have not scaled down our drilling very significantly. So I don't think that there will be any upside in our drilling our program because of drilling moratorium being around.
Okay. Thanks. Thank you sir.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Raj Gandhi from Principle Mutual Fund. Please go ahead.
Hello.
Yes Mr. Gandhi.
Just if you can elaborate a bit, what is the difference between the Declaration of Commerciality and the stage wherein you actually file the FDP and plans are concrete, so how...?
Yeah. So initially a document called Declaration of Commerciality is to be filed.
Okay.

And after that, DGH, the government, they'll work to approve that. Once they approve it, then the operator has got I think maybe one year. So the operator gets further time to file the documents which is the FDP, Field Development Plan, which is a very, very detailed document. It covers that how many play point will be there, how many wells would be there, what would be the production quantity, where the production would come, what would be the production profile? The costs are fine-tuned in terms of CapEx as well as OpEx. So all these details are there. This is a very, very detailed document. This Declaration of Commerciality is a brief document, but based on the technical data which we have today.
Okay, okay. And so just update on Mahanadi block, wherein we did have discovery, but I think we've been quite silent on that since quite some time. Any work going there?
Yeah. Its replied by Mr. Sanjiv Kumar.
Actually we have plans for three to four appraisal wells in the Mahanadi basin...
Okay.
And that will be taken once we are done with this KG 98/2. Ideally one or two wells are planned during the next two years. Based on that we will go for the assessment.
Okay. One or two wells during the next one-year.
Yeah.
Okay, sir. Thanks a lot.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Vishwas Katela from HDFC Standard Life. Please go ahead.
Hello, sir. I don't know whether you have covered this. Basically depreciation cost for the quarter was higher year-on-year. Is there any specific reason to it?

Yes. There is a specific reason to that. The first reason was the commencement of production from Rajasthan block in a significant way. And I think there was an effect of 60 crore of depreciation charged for Rajasthan block. In addition that the existing facility for the existing production, some more facilities have come, though the production has not gone up significantly. So because of that, after all depreciation charges increased.
Okay. Apart from Rajasthan block?
There has been
Okay. And what was your share in volume terms from the Rajasthan block.
I think one of my colleagues who deals with pre tax.
Okay.
The Rajasthan block, we have taken 133 metric ton of oil in the first quarter.
Okay, okay.
Yes.
Okay. That's it from me. Thank you sir.
Thank you. There's a follow up question from the line of Vidyadhar Ginde from DSP Merrill Lynch; please go ahead. Mr. Vidyadhar, your line has been unmated, you may go ahead please.

Yeah. The question I wanted to ask, a couple of questions. One is that, of the exploration variance planned in the current year, how many are planned in NELP blocks and in the Eastern Offshore region, one. And the second question was, as far as the Rajasthan field is concerned, how much reserves, 2P reserves have been accommodated in this field as of the number which you gave us for March 2010?

The first part of the question, I'll take the answer. Out of the total number of exploratory wells planned for the year, 154, roughly around 10 to 15% of the wells have been over the last two three years they have increased, so if we even try to maintain the same figure, around 15% of the rents will be in the NELP block.
Thanks. And on the Rajasthan question.
What's the question you had for Rajasthan?

The question I had is, that of the reserves which you had mentioned to us as 2P reserves as of March 2010, how much of these reserves are from the Rajasthan block, where you have 30% stake along with Kim.

Vidyadhar, it's likely that the REC, Research Activation Committee, once in two years for estimating the results in nomination blocks. And for these, the DSC block, it fits only once a year, and the significant location has been in the current quarter, in the category of crude oil reserves. So, we don't have any upgraded results as to who does those results, but from 10% if we were to provide these results, we have used the results which the team has used for their decision.
So, but the number which you gave us in March 2010 is only of nomination blocks. It has even nothing from the pre NELP Rajasthan block?
No, it has to be there, because in Rajasthan we have only pre NELP block, we don't have any nomination blocks.
No, no I know that, but so therefore you gave us a 2P reserves number of ONGC in India, or a figure of JV as well as nomination of March 2010?
Yes.
So does the JV 2P reserves as of March 2010 include something from Rajasthan?
Nothing. It does include .
But what is that amount, I wanted to find out.
I don't have that number right away with me.
Okay, thanks.
Thank you. The next question is from the line of Rajesh Ghoghari from Religare Capital Market. Please go ahead.

So this is Vallabh here. I've got a couple of questions, one is the ramp up of things. Imperial Energy, how you see the ramp up for that? The second thing, the second question is the number of deepwater wells you are going to drill this year and the next year?
Think Mr. Rakesh Sharma from ONGC will take the Imperial question and then deepwater question we will take up.

The Imperial at the moment is producing at the rate of 1,7000 barrels a day and we expect that its going to be more or less the same, except for a little upside that we are going to have once the weather window is good for carrying out exploration wells and development wells. More or less, this is going to be the case for this yearend and in the next calendar, in the first quarter will see some little upside coming out from Imperial.

So just want to add on that, because I am not wrong, initially you guided for a pretty high number. What we are seeing is that like the ramp up is not going as per that. So any specific reason for that?

Yes. The first reason that I would enumerate is the technical challenge that is being forced up by the reservoir. The reserves are ample over there, it's only the question of reservoir bleeding it out the wells.

Now the reservoir as you would know had just commenced production when we took it over. So this reservoir was not fully examined for its production features. As and when we started drilling wells and going along enhancing the production, we have encountered some difficulty in the form of hydro fracturing the reservoir so that it can bleed.

There are a couple of skills which are still being tested and once these tests move out, we will implement them on full scale and that probably is going to add to enhanced production at Imperial. Till that time we are carrying our studies on hydro fracturing and to hold up the fracture, so that it can bleed.

We would like to retain this kind of level that we have achieved till now, starting from 6,000 when we took over, today its almost 17,000 barrels a day. So we like to maintain this profile, as well experiment and then take something which is very fruitful in the reservoir on a full scale.
Thank you. Question was on the deepwater wells. You will be drilling this year and next year?
This year actually we will be drilling 15 wells. Next year also it will be the same amount, around 15, 16 wells will be there, deep-water wells.
Do you have rig time for that to drill these 15 wells.
I think we have the rig time for drilling all these wells.
I think we are going to have one more rig which is coming by December.
Mr. Ghoghari, do you have any further questions? So we'll move on to the next question. The next question is from the line of Mr. Harshad Borawake from Motilal Oswal. Please go ahead.
Yes. Just wanted to recheck the number of the peak production from the northern development area for gas, could you just repeat that number?
Yes, in south we are quite high; that's why there could be a need for restating that. I said 12.96 BCM up to 2016 which is gas, and 0.841 MMT of oil.
Yes.
Second question was, recently we have heard this $5.25 for the C-series gas pricing, so henceforth whatever incremental gas which we will be getting either from the IO or UR?
Hello?
Hello?
